header.title: The document-v1.1 DTD
header.notice: This document doesn't make any sense at all.
header.abstract: A nonsense document using all possible elements in the current document-v11.dtd.

body.p:
This is a simple paragraph. Most documents contain a fair amount of paragraphs. Paragraphs are called

.
A number of in-line elements are available in the DTD, we will show them inside an unordered list (<ul>):

ul.li: Here is a simple list item (<li>).
Have you seen the use of the <code> element in the previous item?
Also, we have <sub> and <sup> elements to show content above or below the text baseline.
There is a facility to emphasize certain words using the <em> element.
Another possibility is the element: , which offers the ability to refer to an image map.

We have elements for hyperlinking:
<link> use this to link to another document. <jump> use this to jump to another document. <fork> and this one to fork your webbrowser to another document.

Oh, by the way, a definition list was used inside the previous list item. We could put another
unordered list
inside the list item too, but I believe this liberty gets quickly quite hairy as you see.

body.p: So far for the in-line elements, let's look at some paragraph-level elements.
body.fixme: The <fixme> element is used for stuff which still needs work. Mind the author attribute!
body.note: The <code> element is used when the author can't express himself clearly using normal sentences ;-)
body.warning: Sleep deprivation can be the result of being involved in an open source project. (a.k.a. the <warning> element).
body.p: Apart from unordered lists, we have ordered lists too, of course.

ol.li: This should be 3 if my math is still OK.

section.title: Using sections
section.p: You can use sections to put some structure in your document. For some strange historical reason, the section title is an attribute of the <section> element.
